The Model for A National Public Radio System, drafted by
Hartford N. Gunn, Jr., following the November 8, 1968 planning
meeting at WNYC in New York, establishes goals that are attainÂ¬
able and desirable for public radio.
Before any model is activated, there should be reaction
to the proposal which evolved from the planning session.
This is one reaction coupled with a proposed alternative.
(Referral to the initial document will be of assistance as this
paper is studied.)
I. Status of Radio Today.
The evaluation of the status of radio today is, perhaps, too
harsh. It is realistic. Our principal concern must be what
radio can be and what it can do. The network structure
should be built on a foundation of existing stations.
II. The Basic System.
The suggestion that "listeners must be able to identify this
sort of programming (public radio) in a flash" is desirable
but impractical. We would agree with the concept that the
programming must have a character and, if possible, a "sound".
